title: At what age should I start reading to my child? - Quora

response.answer_text: I know Ian McCullough asked me to answer this question because he knows me and knew in advance what my answer would be.  The reasons you read to your embryo and fetus prenatally and as often as you can are many.  While expectant parents might feel silly at first reading to a slowly swelling belly, the sound of your voices reading is soothing, so the oxytocin in mother-baby increases, causing serenity and calm feelings. This is a way to reduce stress in mother-baby during the entire period of gestation.  Additionally, it has been proven that the uterus conducts sound. Babies who have been read to in utero recognize their parents' voices when they are born.  Neonates and infants who are read to feel soothed by familiar voices. Although they may not specifically speak or understand words (understanding predates speaking in the child development process), they are learning the rhythms and patterns of speech. This includes a gradual ability to learn and separate their language's sounds.  Children in preschool who have been read to habitually have an easier time learning the alphabet, and recognizing the sounds of the alphabet in words they know, and can respond accurately to the question: "What sound begins the word 'tiger'?" They have an understanding of language and reasoning that some may say shows early and advanced skills. Actually, they just had more and earlier exposure to language and the sounds and thoughts manifested in speech. Such babies are way ahead of the learning curve.  This answer should be interpreted to mean that as soon as a pregnancy is confirmed, reading aloud can (and should ideally) commence.  Readers whose children are already born should begin the reading aloud habit immediately.  Family reading time before bed is a beautiful ritual. And on weekends and slow summer days, the time from 2-4 was known as 'quiet time' (comprised of afternoon rest and reading time in my household). During that time, children who need to nap can be read to, and then either fall asleep or look at books. Older children can read to themselves or do any quiet independent activity which doesn't interfere with anyone else's quiet time.  Reading out loud can be the greatest moments of a child's life. Edited to add that I am such a proponent of reading with children that I began a blog on Quora, Bedtime Reading. There, you will find answers by parents and by me which list favorite bedtime reading books for parents and kids of all ages.

In the womb?. Immediately upon birth? And never stop. The sound, tone and rhythm of your voice even at the youngest age will have developmental benefits for your child even before they can understand language. It’s helps their brains grow and it may help them develop language faster. Studies have shown that reading to even very young children helps their brains grow and increases intelligence among other benefits. And you don’t always have to read. With very young kids get picture books and talk about the pictures - the figures, the colors, objects in the picture, make up stories. When I was very young my some of my favorite books were Richard Scary books. Back then they didn’t always have words or minimal words but dad and I would spend ages just looking at everything going on in the pictures because there was always A LOT going on. And when Gold Bug became a thing we always searched for it. My dad took me to the library regularly and read to me almost every night and his ‘reading’ always included discussions of the pictures. I was always in the highest reading class in school, always read above my grade level and read my first no pictures chapter book (Nancy Drew) all the way through in one day the summer after fourth grade. I was nine or ten. The beginning of my speed reading ability. I always credit my father not only with giving me the love of books and words but giving me the freedom of imagination and the freedom and skills to indulge all of those things because he opened my mind to the worlds in books from a very young age.

Reading to children should begin as soon as the child is capable of understanding even a few words, possibly even before. Many books for very young children consist almost entirely of pictures, and looking at the pictures together and turning the pages helps establish the desirability of reading and emphasises companionship between adult and child. It’s also a very good way to help settle children for sleep. We had a few books which revolved around just a few words that were excellent for very young children. One involved the word Boo! which our son learned to recognise very early; he’d point to it and yell “Boo!” In its way, that established in his mind that he could or would be able to read when the time came. In fact, reading sort of snuck up on him. He came home from school one day and said to me, with an odd, somewhat disgusted, look on his face: “I discovered I can read.” (I’d actually known he could for some months before his discovery.)

Reading to them while they're in the womb, and every night you can stay awake enough to see words from the birth. Or - to be more accessible to those us without access to a time machine: Start now. Get books with pictures, read the words to her (pointing to them) but also point to different parts of the pictures and describe them, describe what's happening - do it every night, do it during the day, get at least two really good kiddie books to read per day. Read all the time - let her see you do it for fun for yourself. Read out bits of books you're reading for her to listen to (not violent or smexy bits - but otherwise don't worry about the words not meaning anything to her or being too complicated - get her used to hearing them). Read in waiting rooms, read at bed time, read in the middle of the day, just read - read out her cereal packets. Just get her used to the rhythm. And then - when she turned 2 years old - start watching "Super Why!" with her (can be found on YouTube - and you can start when she's one if you really wanted to but it's really above that age group - and you kind of want to hit JUST above her age group - but not too far that she can't get any enjoyment out of it - I started my son on Super Why when he was 2 years old - at 3 years old (and now at 4) he was causing professionals to jaw drop on his recognition of letters).

Hi there , I see that this question is well answered by Radhika Alok. You can start when the baby is still in the womb. The earlier you start the better as the interest is inculcated at a stage when the child learns that which you teach and not when they are being influenced by outside environment. Reading with a lot of expressions and sounds and acting makes the story come alive and the child enjoys it so much more. His /her imagination is sparked and after that it is a lifetime habit. The important thing is that at very young age do not expect that they understand right and complete the story and sound the word right. It is about getting the child’s interest. So you could be funny and come up with silly words and even go to the extent of changing the story with twist from the normal. You could also make up stories with them. As they grow a little older do introduce different topics for them to become versatile. Regular reading creates a love for books and forms a lifetime habit. Reading once a week or only when you have time is not the method. You should inculcate the habit of reading yourself if you are not a reader. Start with newspaper and articles and short stories and magazines then go on to fatter books.

This is an opinion of a proud daddy of a great 9 year old.  Reading to your little one can become a unique experience, but don't do it as an "investment" with future benefits in mind (nothing wrong with it, only it's less good and it could even backfire); instead, imagine those minutes spent sharing a story, with its pictures, its theatrics, where *you* have your FUN(!!). Play and laughter will spontaneously create an experience that connects you both at the heart -- and during those minutes we forget about her IQ, about her learning, her knowledge, future mini-habits; instead, we seize the moment and have a blast. Then make it a tradition, so you help her grow wiser while she helps you grow younger. And well, while that's not the point, I'd say that if it is in her, this tradition is all she'll need to love reading. If I am 1% right about the above, I would say that it's never too early. Focus on having fun, so select your material wisely (don't start with Ulysses or The Iliad...).

I'd encourage you to start well before the actual words make any sense to your child. There's something nice about the cadence of mom or dad's voice, sharing words in a friendly way, that gets the reading habit started.  And, of course, if it's a picture book, you're turning the pictures and pointing to items of interest. Some of that will register at a very tiny age. Starting now is just fine. Both of you will be surprised and delighted as comprehension starts to click in during the months ahead. Some favorites in our house were Good Night, Gorilla, as well as Counting Crocodiles and Sheep in a Jeep.  But in a pinch, almost anything will work. I made a go of the  Gettysburg Address once. You can even read your boss's emails, which --  if you get the tone just right -- will leave both of you howling with  laughter. Be warned: your kids may want to hear the same story 30x or more.

I am so qualified to answer this :) The earlier you start the better it is for the baby! With my little munchkin I started reading to her starting from when she was a month old. And not to forget reading to the baby when you are pregnant. The more you talk or speak to the baby when you are expecting them, the faster they recognise your voice when born. The familiar voice they heard in the womb soothes the new born and makes them feel better. My little one is hardly 16 months now and absolutely loves books and enjoys being read to. It is such a positive distraction from the tech savy world around them. I would happily read to her the whole day rather than let her watch TV or play on the mobile phones. Reading to babies is a great way to introduce them to the world of books and inculcate in them a love for reading. Also it helps you form a special bond with the little ones. One of my greatest pleasures as a mother is to see my baby turn pages of just any book she can lay her hands on. And oh. Yeah.. Be prepared for a lot of pulling and tearing of the pages. Go for board books till they learn that books shouldn't be torn.

As soon as possible. Start with bedtime stories. Perhaps you can narrate stories in the beginning and then slowly begin reading it out to them. Kids in general love listening to stories. Once they get hooked to stories, start reading out from books. Chance are, they will ask you to repeat their favorite stories many times.T Be patient. Once they are older, this will make them want to read the stories on their own. And you will have a child who's proficient in the language. If you belong to a place more than one language is spoken/studied, read out stories in both the languages. Good luck!  Be your own sunshine and choose to be happy! UK

As soon as they are able to enjoy it. Whenever they are interested in sitting and looking at a book with you.  At first you are probably just going to be showing them the book instead of "reading" but it paves the way.  When they get older you can read more interesting and challenging books.  When they are old enough, take them to the library and have them help choose books to read. Get stacks of books and if you get a dud, you don't need to read it. I always liked to ask questions about the story or comment on it.  I think it is good to keep it up even after they can read on their own. But by the time they are 8 or 9 or so the window starts to close. They read faster on their own than you can speak so they are off and running on their own. Some books you may read many many many times. In fact some I read so often and in a state of sleep deprivation that I found myself having completed reading it and having no memory of even turning the pages.  Enjoy it while you can and keep it fun and happy.

You should begin reading to your child as soon as he is born. I remember reading aloud to my children while they nursed. It didn’t matter that the book I was reading was the one from my night table. Board books. are fun to “read” together even for a very young baby. They enjoy looking at the pictures and hearing mom or dad point things out and say what they are, and they make fine teething toys when reading is over. Picture books are wonderful for the very young. Simple stories help teach sounds for learning to talk. But, when they’re infants, it doesn’t matter what you read, as long as you read something. Good luck!

I don't think it would hurt to start at the most early stages of life. I want to tell you somethings about the Islamic child development practices. It may not explain anything for certain but it gives you something to ponder upon. When a child is born, on the third day after their birth, a revered person or the father holds the kid and recite in their right ear the call to prayer (Athan), then to their left ear the start to prayer (Iqama). These are words attesting the concept of Islam, that is there is no God but Allah and Muhammad is His Messenger. This also happens to be the same thing a child hears (even if they don't understand it) at least five times a day. The outcome: these words usually end up as the first words a child learns and thus imprinted on their minds forever. This is to give you an insight on how reading to a child at an early age gives a head start and becomes an advantage. The main derivative is the recitation of the Qur'an at the earliest to the child. Thus in the manner now being exemplified, you have Muslim children memorizing the whole 114 chapters of the Holy Qur'an by heart in as little as 7 years old. One can say that it is just specific to the Holy book but you should get the point. Start now and help give this world one more bright future through your child.

Start reading to your children 9 months before their birth and never stop. I guess you could quit when they start college...l mean...well. Meaning, before they are born. Reading to them is so important. My daughter was about 4 or 5 and l was reading “Gone With the Wind”. My daughter ask me about reading all that and not getting to see anyone. I told her l cold see so sorts of pictures. I told her to close her eyes and listen while l tell her about Scarlett. I found a very descriptive paragraph describing how Scarlett looked while flirting with all the boys. After l had finished reading there paragraph daughter said, “Scarlett is so beautiful.” I am her how did she know, they're are no pictures here. She said,” because l can see her in my head.” From that point on my daughter was a very avid reader and l read to her very often.

You can start now.  Today.  Tonight.  Tomorrow morning. My daughter is 9 months and I think I know what you'll say.  They don't sit still!  The first place I started reading to her was when she was sitting in the chair where she likes to go to pass a bowel movement.  Or if she is standing in one place for a few seconds.  And I also try to do it just before bedtime. Some suggestions:  1.  First Book of Sushi - has bright red and black pictures with fun rhyming words, even better if you actually eat the stuff with your kid; 2.  Moo, Baa, Laa Laa Laa.  This is a crowd-pleaser up into the 3-4 year old group.  3.  Hungry Caterpillar.   They won't pay attention much.  They'll try to chew on the book.  It's ok - it's not actually about the reading, it's about the sounds and the habit. ENJOY!

If you aren’t reading or making up stories, you should be singing, beginning with newborns. It relaxes them and helps you too. It is a way of having your baby be connected to you early on, and language is a bonus also. I read to my children long after they could read to themselves. I just dug out the Raggedy Ann and Andy series for my great grandchildren. They are full of adventures where nothing much happens, so I hope they will still enjoy them.

I want to add that you don't have to have the child on your lap to read with them. When my oldest was a baby, he would sit and listen to as many books as I would read. When my son was young, as soon as he could squirm out of my arms he would. One day I decided to keep reading as he crawled around the room. When I would stop reading, he would crawl over to me and stare at me or pat the book. He was actually listening and enjoying the book even though he wasn't looking at it. My sons are now 10 and 12 and both avid readers. I contribute that to the fact that 1.) We started reading to them early 2.) We surrounded them with plenty of books to choose from and didn't freak out when the pages were torn (after all, a pristine book is an unread book) 3.)We made sure that they saw us reading for fun as well, be it a magazine or book.

This is an answer where everyone can have an opinion. At birth, the baby won’t necessarily understand words and colors, but will receive the warm feelings of cuddling with a good book. On the other hand, babies are pretty exhausting for the parents at that time, so don’t feel badly if you can’t get to it. It becomes more important to read for reading’s sake as the child gets ready to enter pre-school. Read, read, read grades K-2 for sure. As the child gets older, let the child choose books and trade off reading. There is so much good to be gained from reading to, then later with, your child. Make it your pleasure.

I suggest you begin reading to your children as early as possible. They may simply sit on your lap and touch pictures, but the sooner they can learn that books are interesting and fun the better. What a very young child gleans from time with books is immeasurable. Even letting the child simply handle the books and gain a sense that books are for them is valuable. Try to make book time as entertaining as you can. Use funny voices and expressive face gestures that will keep them engaged. For babies consider getting books that have tactile aspects as well. Small children love feeling different textures. My young children also loved books that had music at a touch of a button. You are in for a magical time of watching your little one come to love books and the time you and they spend enjoying them together.

We started reading right away because it's just a nice way to cuddle up while doing something together. Picture books at first, but moving on to rhyming books shortly after because re-reading them was like listening to a familiar song. When he was a bit older still, I'd use my finger to emphasize that the sounds were coming from the words, and point out the occasional easy word that repeated throughout the book. I don't know if this happens for all kids but at some point our boy started rejecting books and we just let him. It lasted about a month, (probably) when he realized books weren't something we were pushing on him. At 6, he's a avid reader.

This is an old question, but I'll answer anyway. “As soon as you can!” My parents read to me as early as I can remember (at 40, I can still remember a few things from when I was 1 or 2). It encouraged me to want to learn to read at a very young age. I even asked my mom to label things around the house to help me learn! It fostered my love of stories and storytelling. It encouraged my creative development. I would often expound upon the stories, adding my own elements and continuing the adventures! More importantly, in my opinion, it reinforced the bonds between us. Read to your child, as early and often as you can, while you can.

Start reading with your baby as soon as possible! They aren’t going to be able to read. In fact, there’s a good chance she won’t even understand the words you’re reading to her. But that doesn’t mean you shouldn’t sit down with a good book! Early literacy is begun by understanding the most basics parts of books. The direction in which we turn the pages. The way the letters look on the page. Even the way a book opens and closes. Aside from that, the words you read to your child will help to improve her vocabulary tremendously! Make it a habit to read with your baby, even if it’s just for a few minutes each day. Go check out this helpful article I found that tackles child development. Definitely a good read! Your Smart Baby - KidsBaron - Kids, Family and Baby Supplies

Without a doubt, the first night home with the baby in the crib (or on the bed next to you). Even if it seems like you're reading to the air, your baby can hear everything you are saying. Over time, their mind will make sense of what you're saying. Before you know it, seriously, your baby will understand everything you're saying. About six months later, you will hear your baby's first words. Language learning works like this: Listen, Speak/Read, Write. Understanding comes way before speaking. But you don't need to be able to speak a word to be able to read it. You just need to be able to understand it. An example being: diaphragm. I knew this word before I knew how to say it. I knew what it meant and by seeing it, I knew what it was. But it was a while before I could pronounce it correctly. That and Hermoine Granger. ;p

Day one or before. Reading to your child, even as an infant or even as a fetus is a wonderful connection between a parent, father or mother, and their child.   Of course a child’s interaction with what’s being read will change over time, with progressive cognition and may well pass through a lot of chewing. One of my favorite storytimes books for children of all ages is Charlie Parker plated Be Bop by Chris Rachke  It’s art work is magic and the word sounds are more important than meaning. Anything read with a soft, shooting and loving manner will work.

It's never too early to start reading to your child. Do it every night. I still try to do it nightly (though usually half the time) with my 6, 8 and 10 yr old. I will be sad when they won't allow me to do this anymore.

I think confronting children with literature and pictures has not much to do with age. As mother you will know when she is starting to pay attention to pictures. That is the first stage. If you can keep her interest then you will explain things on the picture and keep repeating funny sounds. Eventually you will take it a step further and explain simple story lines. You can improve and build the attention span with the same book again and again. Kids just love the familiar. Once she talks, she will tell her own story. Don't correct her unless she asks for it. The story itself is of secondary importance. The illustrations and her imagination is everything. I created my series for my grandchildren. They grew up with "Oliver and Jumpy" and were asking for more stories all the time. It was an event for them to see what Oliver was up to again! Download two free books with marvellous illustrations to introduce your daughter to this bestselling series. bedtimestory4you.com

Day one from the time they are born. My son by the time he was two years old he knew his letters and numbers. By the time he was three and with a great pre school he was able to read and write his name. Also whatever my kids had to read i read tge books as well. So we could discuss the what they have read. By the time my son reachrd 7th grade he tested 12th grade level. I sent him to Catholic school. From the 4th to 6th grade. EDUCATION STARTS AT home. So everything a parent does the child learns its starts with talking. So get all kinds of books and flash cards and start Kids learn symbols early for example McDonalds was smart with the Arches. Children automatically knows its McDonalds.
Read now, read anything, read everything.Surround her with books to play with.

I read to both my kids when they were newborns. I made it part of the bedtime ritual. I'd nurse, then read, then put them to bed. Just simple books like "Goodnight, Moon," and similar things. I did this for years, the books obviously getting more complex as they got older. My daughter is seven and we still read a book together before she goes to bed; my son (11) often reads by himself before he goes to sleep.  The important thing is to read to your kids. Have books around for them to look at, whether there are words or just pictures. Kids put stuff together and it doesn't always have to be the symbols we know as letters. Start the habit, and give them the materials to keep it gong.

You should already be reading with your baby. One advantage of lots of parental reading to babies and young children is that they become familiar with the sounds of formal literary language. This gives the child a huge head start in reading down the road! They are native speakers of literary English, which makes learning to read .literary English a snap. it's hard enough figuring outhow to decode without also trying to understand the phraseology of the text! Please, please, go to your local library and ask the children's librarian for some recommendations, and just start! You'll both love it, I promise you!

I started reading to my two daugthers since they were still in the womb and continued reading to them all the time until today. Now the big one, 6 years old, loves to read for me, her sister or anyone who wants to hear her. And the little one "read" any book with pictures and tells us some of the best stories I have ever heard. In the school both are way over their partners in language development and understanding. Their teachers constantly talk about their easyness to understand new concepts and to include new words in their vocabulary. I strongly believe that one of the best gifts you can give to someone is the love for reading.

Start now! Find some texture books that you can both enjoy-Pat the Bunny is one- and start making a habit of some quiet time together before bedtime. Books with flaps to lift up are great too. It doesn't have to even have words to be "reading", just your voice describing what you see and asking her to find things in the pictures will go,a long way toward her language acquisition. Enjoy, this is a precious time.

Soon as you can - show them pictures, they love catalogues too ( why?) and anything you can pick up or find with pictures and photos - then move on to stories with pictures, then stories, It is so good for their concentration and vocab and everything - and having your time and attention is precious.
Birth it's never too early you can bond with your new born over a book they might not understand all the words but your tone and the closeness is so valuable

My daughter was 7 hours old when I read her first book to her.  Babies often respond well to rhymes.  They are short and you can bounce them on your knee to the rhythm.  Short and sweet is the key.  We  love board books for their durability.  Lindsay Dodd is a fantastic author and her Hairy Maclairy books have a good mix of rhythm and story and are available as board books.  Mem Fox's "It's Time for Bed" was my daughter's first story.  The Usborne "That's Not My..." series is great for little ones.  It's repetitive, tactile and durable.

Before their eyes can focus to be able to see a picture book Talk to a new baby, read short rhyming sentences. The brain of a newborn is a miraculous organ, beginning to learn immediately when baby is born and hearing voices AND music. Bach, Beethoven, Mozart, classical symphonies, soft and soothing.

Reading, singing, talking are all forms of communication , so you can start them from day 1. A mothers voice really calms down the baby, it is very comforting so that way it is useful right away from the very start.

Reading can start as early as 1 week.  Our granddaughter was read to by both mother and dad when she was a week one and she was fascinated by the voice, the book, the pictures (though we know she could't focus well then).  She is now three and is still loving books, knows letters and their sounds and can make a connection between some words and objects.   Don't wait!
I began reading to my first child when he was six months old. IMHO you should start there at the latest. Babies love the rhythm of your voice and the change of visuals.
Many parents start reading to their child when they're in the womb. The earlier your child is exposed to reading, the sooner she will understand the concept and learn it.

Around 18 weeks of pregnancy, your little one hears their very first sounds. By 24 weeks, those little ears are rapidly developing. Your baby's sensitivity to sound will improve even more as the weeks pass. The limited sounds your baby hears around this point in your pregnancy are noises you may not even notice… Before your baby enters the world, and after..LOVE..

Read to them from the day they came home from the hospital! Your voice being heard by them a lot will create a bind between the two of you, and the sooner you start reading to them, the sooner they will want to learn how to read for themselves.

You can never start reading too early. Especially picture books as they will help her satisfy the curiosity she has as a child and help her learn more about the world. Just make sure this is not a task but more a of a fun activity for you and her so she can associate positive feelings with reading.

There is no prescribed age. The earlier you start the better it is. You can start as early as 6 to 12 months. At very young ages sit beside them and “read” from picture books. As they grow expand your field.
As early as possible. Even if they are too young to understand what you are saying. The love to hear your voice and it stimulates their brain.
Two yeas will be a suitable age for reading them. Reading enhances children imagination and strengths the bond between parents and children.
2 maybe, for books for their age. It's never too early, really … or too late to start. The benefits are HUGE. Kids who love to read have a major advantage in school, college, and life.
As early as possible. The 1st 3 years are the most important in a child's development and reading to it as early as possible helps the baby develop

Very early. You do not have to wait for him to speak or even understand. In order to promote his speech you can start showing him picture books and naming the people and things in them as soon as he can concentrate for a moment.
The moment their eyes ca focus on the pictures. On second thought, the moment they can hear your voice. They might not understand anything you are reading, but it will fascinate them anyway.
Agree with George Anders here. Infact some of my thoughts are echoed in this - What Is The Right Age To Start Telling Stories To Your Children
My grandson’s mommy has read to him everyday of his life and he his 4 months old. I would say at some point in the first year.
